The Environmental Manager must exist as Business Partner with up-to-date organizational data to be assigned as the responsible person for monitoring and reporting activities.

An Environmental Technician collects samples and records operational data

The technician must be identifiable as a Business Partner to ensure accountability, traceability, and proper assignment of sampling tasks.

Supplier-provided material data is used to support emission factor calculations

Material master data ‚Äì such as composition, heating values, or supplier relationships ‚Äì must be accurate and synchronized from MDG to ensure correct calculation of emission factors.

SAP EHS aggregates emission data and calculates quarterly NOx emissions

Material attributes and Business Partner assignments form essential input for compliant and reproducible emission calculations.

A deviation is detected, triggering an investigation

The system must determine responsible persons (Business Partner) to initiate corrective actions and assign follow-up tasks.

A Corrective Action Plan is defined and assigned

Task assignments require valid Business Partner information to ensure that responsible roles receive, process, and complete corrective actions.

Findings are shared with Sustainability and Operations teams

Consistent organizational Business Partner data ensures that notifications and reporting reach the correct stakeholder groups across sites.

Without integrated Business Partner and Material data, the system would not be able to:

  • Identify responsible persons (Environmental Manager, Technician, etc.)
  • Use complete and reliable material attributes in emission calculations
  • Track corrective actions or investigation responsibilities
  • Produce compliant and auditable emissions reports

Note: Although employees such as the Environmental Manager or the Environmental Technician could technically be replicated from SAP SuccessFactors, this alone is not sufficient for Emissions Management. The SAP SuccessFactors integration delivers Workforce Persons, which are used for people-related EHS processes (e.g., workflows, incident reporting, assignments). Emissions Management, however, requires full Business Partner master data ‚Äì including organizational roles, supplier relationships, and external parties ‚Äì that SAP SuccessFactors does not provide. These Business Partners are essential for material classification, supplier-dependent emission factors, regulatory reporting, and responsibilities that are not limited to internal employees.

This makes the integration of Business Partner and Material master from SAP MDG into SAP EHS Public Cloud a mandatory prerequisite for configuring Emissions Management.

Note: When implementing Emissions Management as shown in the User Scenario, ensure that the relevant scope item ‚Äì 4XD ‚Äì Emissions Management ‚Äì is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC). This activation enables the Emissions Management processes and configuration in SAP EHS Public Cloud so that the replicated Business Partner and Material master data can be used for monitoring, calculating, and reporting emissions.

While this integration is mandatory for Emissions Management, it is equally relevant for other EHS use cases such as Risk Management or Incident Management. In these scenarios, consistent master data ensures reliable assignment of responsibilities, correct categorization of materials, and accurate process execution. Across the organization.

Therefore, in the following section, we will take a closer look at the general setup of the Business Partner and Material data integration between SAP MDG and SAP EHS Public Cloud.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully integrate Business Partner and Material Master data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled. These ensure that master data replication works seamlessly and support EHS processes such as Emission Management.

To successfully set up this integration scenario, the following prerequisites must be in place:

Tenant Provisioning:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant
  • SAP MDG system should be available as the source system.

Administrator Access: Ensure administrator users exist in both systems:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: The administrator should have the template role of SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR assigned to allow creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements.
  • SAP MDG for replication framework setup.

Scope Item Activation:

While this section focuses on the setup required for Emission Management, the same integration scenario also enables other EHS functionalities like Incident Management and Risk Management. For these processes, the corresponding scope items described in part 1 must be activated:

  • 3FP ‚Äì Incident Management
  • 54A ‚Äì Risk Management

In our scenario for Emission Management following scope items were activated:

  • 1RO ‚Äì Master Data Integration
    • Purpose: Provides the technical foundation for master data replication, including communication scenarios for Business Partner (SAP_COM_0008) and Material Master (SAP_COM_0009).
    • Why: Without 1RO, the integration cannot be configured because the required APIs and replication models are not available.
  • 4XD ‚Äì Emissions Management (only if Emission Management is in scope)
    • Purpose: Enables emission-related processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
    • Why: Business Partner and Material Master data serve as the backbone for emission sources and organizational assignments.

Data Requirements:

  • Legal entities in SAP Material Master Governance (MDG) must match the Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Mismatches will lead to replication failures).

Cloud Connector Setup:

To establish secure and reliable communication between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the On-Premise SAP MDG system, the SAP Cloud Connector must be properly configured for this integration scenario.

  • Register the SAP MDG system in the Cloud Connector UI and ensure that the connection is active and reachable.
  • Define a virtual host and port in the Cloud Connector. This virtual host will later be referenced when creating the Communication System in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
  • Ensure  that the SCC Location ID is maintained to link the correct connector instance.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section describes the practical implementation of the master data integration based on the predefined 1RO ‚Äì Master Data Integration scope item. It outlines how Business Partner and Material Master data are replicated from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and highlights the key configuration areas involved in the process.

The 1RO scope item provides the standard integration scenario for master data replication and supports related data flows that are essential for EHS processes such as Incident Management, Risk Management, and Emission Management. Accurate and consistent master data is crucial for these use cases, as organizational structures, business partners, and material information form the foundation for compliance and operational processes.

Therefore, this section focuses on the Business Partner and Material Master integration processes, which serve as the backbone for all subsequent EHS configurations.

Key 1RO Configuration Areas:

  • Communication User and Communication System setup for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • Business Partner Integration (SAP_COM_0008)
  • Product Integration (SAP_COM_0009)
  • Configure Message Monitoring SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

For detailed documentation, please refer to the official 1RO content in the SAP Process Navigator.

1RO Setup Instructions as PDF

3.1 Communication User & Communication System Setup for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

The integration scenario in this chapter enables the replication of Business Partner and Material Master data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

This is achieved by using the predefined communication scenarios delivered by SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:

  • SAP_COM_0008 ‚Äì Business Partner Integration
  • SAP_COM_0009 ‚Äì Product Integration

Both scenarios form part of the activated scope item 1RO ‚Äì Master Data Integration, which provides the APIs and replication models required for master data exchange between SAP MDG and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

In our setup, SAP_COM_0008 and SAP_COM_0009 were both assigned to one shared Inbound Communication User and one shared Communication System. The differentiation between scenarios is handled within the Communication Arrangement, where scenario-specific service endpoints and authentication settings are maintained.

3.1.1 Create Inbound Communication User

The Inbound Communication User is required for authenticating inbound calls from SAP MDG to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. We created a dedicated user (e.g. MDG_IN) using the ‚ÄúMaintain Communication Users‚Äù app in the SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Select Maintain Communication User

 If no suitable user exists, a new one must be created by choosing ‚ÄúNew‚Äù.

Select New Communication User

 The username and password for Basic Authentication can be defined freely.

Illustration of our Communication User - Overview

Once created, the system automatically structures the user view, showing assignments to Communication Systems and Arrangements (added in later steps).

Illustration of our Communication User - Assigned Communication System & Arrangements

 3.1.2 Create Communication System

The Communication System represents the technical connection between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the external SAP MDG system. It includes critical configuration information such as: Hostname, authentication method, inbound/outbound communication users, technical identifiers used for secure system-to-system communication.

Note: Unlike the JB1 employee replication in part 2 (chapter 3.2), which connected SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to SAP Integration Suite, the 1RO master data scenario connects SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud directly to the SAP MDG On-Premise system. This scenario is SOAP-based and does not involve middleware. Therefore, SAP MDG ats as the external Business System in the Communication System setup.

If no applicable Communication System exists, a new one must be created via the ‚ÄúCommunication Systems‚Äù app.

Select Communication SystemsSelect New Communication System

Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) tenant and proceed with the set up.

After creating the new Communication System entry, additional configuration details must be maintained ‚Äì including Technical Data, User for Inbound Communication and User for Outbound Communication. These parameters define how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud connects with the external SAP MDG tenant. For comprehensive configuration guidance, refer to the 1RO setup instructions.

Communication System Setup - Technical Data 1

Note: As we are connecting a cloud system to an on-premise system, the SAP Cloud Connector needs to be added to the Communication System. If your on-premise system is currently not linked via any Cloud Connector, please refer to your SAP BASIS admin. Once the SAP MDG On-Premise system is added as mentioned before, the Cloud Connector then provides a secure tunnel and enables the use of virtual host names and its corresponding virtual port, which can be viewed in the SAP BTP Cockpit via Connectivity > Cloud Connectors. These values must be maintained as Host Name and Port in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Communication System.

Additionally, the SCC Location ID must be maintained in the Communication System to ensure the correct connector instance is used. As the SCC Location ID is only visible in the UI of the Cloud Connector, please refer to your BASIS admin to get the SCC Location ID. For further information you can have a look in the SAP Help Portal.

For the Business System, we added our SAP MDG tenant and configured the Logical System using the SAP MDG system‚Äòs runtime URL. It is important to enter the runtime URL without the ‚ÄûHTTPS:/‚Äú prefix as the protocol is handled separately during the communication setup.

Because we are using Basic Authentication, all other advanced communication settings ‚Äì including RFC Settings, OAuth 2.0 Settings, Event Exchange Infrastructure, Remote SQL Access, and Identify Provider configurations ‚Äì were intentionally left empty or set to offline, as they are not required for our case.

Communication System Setup - Technical Data 2

Communication System Setup - Identify Provider

For the Inbound Communication User, we selected the one created in the previous step.

The Outbound Communication User does not necessarily come from the ‚ÄúMaintain Communication Users‚Äù app. It can be any technical user in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system with the required authorizations for outbound communication. In productive scenarios, it is recommended to use a dedicated technical user for this purpose.

Communication System Setup - Users for Inbound & Outbound Communication

If any Communication Arrangements are assigned (will be explained in later sections), they will be visible within this Communication System.

Communication System Setup - Overview of assigned Communication Arrangements

3.2 Business Partner Integration

3.2.1 Communication Arrangement for Integration Scenario SAP_COM_0008

In the Communication Arrangement, the previously created components (Communication User and Communication System), have been linked within the integration scenario SAP_COM_0008. This arrangement consolidated the technical connection and authentication setup by combining the Communication System (representing the external MDG system) with the appropriate Inbound and Outbound Communication Users. Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is prepared to receive replicated Business Partner master data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG).

The Communication Arrangement also provided the inbound service URL required for the MDG replication and enables secure, consistent data exchange as part of the 1RO scope item.

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the ‚ÄúCommunication Arrangements‚Äù app.

Select Communication Arrangements

 Then click on ‚ÄúNew‚Äù to create a new Communication Arrangement.

Create New Communication Arrangement

 Choose SAP_COM_0008 as the Communication Scenario.

Assign Communication ScenarioSelect Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0008

After that, further setting configurations needs to be done. Therefore, the before created Communication System will be attached.

Add Communication System to Communication Arrangement

Take note of the value maintained in the field ‚ÄúOwn SAP Cloud System‚Äù (see screenshot below). This value is required when configuring the external MDG system, where it must be entered in fields such as System Instance ID, Business System ID, or IDoc Logical System ID during the setup of the corresponding integration settings.

In our case, the fields under ‚ÄúAdditional Properties‚Äù remained empty.

Own SAP Cloud System in Communication Arrangement

Based on the selected Inbound Communication User, the system automatically derives the user for this Communication Arrangement. The Inbound Services listed in this section can remain unchanged. Their respective Service URLs are generated automatically from the API base URL ad the service-specific path.

Communication Arrangement Setup - Inbound Communication User

For Outbound Communication, the system automatically derives the User Name from the assigned Communication System.

By default, all Outbound Services are set to ‚ÄúActive‚Äù. The predefined Service URL and Basic Type can remain unchanged, as these values are generated automatically.

Since our integration scenario replicates Business Partner data from the on-premise SAP MDG system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, we follow the guidelines described in chapter 3.1.5 of the scope item in the 1RO setup instructions, page 16. According to these guidelines, all Outbound Services must be set to ‚ÄúInactive‚Äù, except for:

  • Business Partner ‚Äì Send Confirmation from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Client
  • BP Relationship ‚Äì Send Confirmation from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to Client

These two services must remain active so that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud can send confirmation messages back to the source system (SAP MDG) after successful processing. This ensures proper synchronization attempts within the Data Replication Framework.

Communication Arrangement Setup - Required Outbound Services

3.2.2 Integrate Business Partner Data from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

This section focuses on the Business Partner replication setup based on the recommendations of chapter 3.1.5 of the 1RO setup instructions, beginning at page 16. Since the required Outbound Services and Service URLs were already outlined in chapter 3.2.1, we continue here with the configuration of the Inbound Services within Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0008.

To begin the integration setup, the WSDL/Service Metadata for the following Inbound Services from the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system:

  • Business Partner ‚Äì Replicate from Client to SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Business Partner Relationship ‚Äì Replicate from Client to SAPS/4HANA Cloud

Download WSDL Service Metadata from the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0008

Upload WSDL in SAP MDG - SOAMANAGER

In the on-premise SAP MDG system, navigate to SOAMANAGER. According to the 1RO setup instructions, chapter 3.1.5 ‚Äì Procedure ‚Äì sub chapter 4 - page 18, you must choose between a central or decentral configuration approach. In our scenario, we used the decentral configuration.

Navigate to SOAMANAGER in SAP MDG On-Premise System

Note: To enable dynamic receiver determination, the Business Partner web service uses service groups in SOAMANAGER. Consequently, logical ports for the service consumer must not be created manually; instead, they must be generated automatically based on the integration scenario. This requires a WSDL-based configuration.

De-Central Configuration Approach:

We selected the decentralized configuration approach because it provides the flexibility required for our system landscape. While SAP MDG remains the primary source for master data, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud may also perform validations or localized adjustments. A decentralized setup is typically preferred when multiple systems need to manage master data independently, ensuring agility and avoiding reliance on a single central system.

Ensure that the Central Configuration switch is set off for this setup. You can verify this under: Technical Administration > SAP Client Settings > Central Configuration.

De-Central Configuration Approach

After that, we need to upload the before downloaded WSDL/Service Metadata to the on-premise SAP MDG system. Therefore, navigate to Tools > WSDL Upload

Uploading WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - Overview

Create a new entry with the appropriate Name, Description, and WSDL Base with the selected radio button ‚ÄúVia File‚Äù, and upload the first WSDL file. Repeat this step for the second WSDL file as well.

Uploading WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER

Note: The WSDL typically contains several protocol and authentication alternatives. By default, WS-RM and HTTPBasic are selected. If another option is preferred (e.g., SAP-RM), the WSDL must be adjusted prior to upload by removing unneeded alternatives.

Create Entries in Service Registry:

Navigate to Service Registry > Publication of External WSDL.

Publish Uploaded WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - 1

Choose the uploaded WSDL file and follow the instructions of the 1RO setup instructions. The steps you can find in chapter 3.1.5 De-Central Configuration Approach ‚Äì Create Entries in a Service Registry, page 21.

Publish Uploaded WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - 2

 Chapter 3.1.5 - Create Entries in a Service Registry - Page 21

Ensure that in step 7 of the above shown steps, the Own SAP Cloud System is entered in the System Name field, and the corresponding API-URL (as Host Name) is taken from the communication arrangement SAP_COM_0008, as described in chapter 3.2.1.

Publish Uploaded WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - 3

 Own SAP Cloud System in Communication Arrangement

When repeating the WSDL publication step for the BusinessPartnerRelationship WSDL, select the existing Physical System that was created in the previous step.

Publish Uploaded WSDL Service Metadata in MDG On-Premise System via SOAMANAGER - 4

Create Profile:

When integrating via SOAP services, the WSDL only defines the interface. The security profile ensures secure communication by specifying:

  • Authentication (User ID/Password)
  • Transport Security (secured communication)
  • No IBC determination for simplified setup

This profile is referenced by provider systems to enforce consistent security settings for all service calls. Navigate to Technical Administration > Profiles

 

Create Profile in SOAMANAGER - 1

Create the new user as specified above. We created a DEFAULT_PROFILE in our scenario.

Create Profile in SOAMANAGER - 2

Create a Provider System:

The provider system links SAP MDG to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for SOAP-based integration. Navigate to Technical Administration > Provider Systems

Create Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 1

Create the Provider System as mentioned in the 1RO setup instructions. The steps you can find in chapter 3.1.5 De-Central Configuration Approach ‚Äì Create a Provider System, page 21-22.

Chapter 3.1.5 - Create a Provider System - Page 21-22

Use the same Name as maintained in the Own SAP Cloud System of the SAP_COM_0008 Communication Arrangement, and assign the profile created in the previous step.

Create Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 2

For WSDL Access, if no system appears in the value help, select the service registry SR_LOCAL and remove this system from the value help. Ensure that the WSIL Service is deactivated.

Create Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 3

According to WSDL Documents select Basic Authentication and enter the user credentials of your MDG user. Ensure that the Tolerant Search option is enabled under Search Granularity.

Create a Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 4

In the creation step, select Retrieve Business Applications. The system will automatically generate an entry for the business application. Complete the changes afterwards.

Create Provider System in SOAMANAGER - 5

Create logon data:

Creating logon data ensures secure authentication for SOAP communication between SAP MDG and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. It centralizes credential storage and links them to service definitions to support reliable and secure data replication. To configure this, navigate to: Service Administration > Logon Data Management

Create Logon Data in SOAMANAGER - 1

In the Maintenance tab, create a new user if none exists and select User/Password or X.509 as the authentication method. Enter the user of the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system that was created as the Inbound Communication User and maintain the corresponding password.

Create Logon Data in SOAMANAGER - 2

In the Assignment tab, proceed the remaining steps described in the . The steps you can find in chapter 3.1.5 De-Central Configuration Approach ‚Äì Create Logon Data, page 22.

Chapter 3.1.5 - Create Logon Data - Page 22

Create Integration Scenario Configuration:

This step consolidates all previously configured settings into an executable integration scenario and generates the logical ports required for SOAP-based replication. For that, navigate to Service Administration > Local Integration Scenario Configuration.

Create Integration Scenario in SOAMANAGER

As all required settings required for this step are mentioned in the previous steps, you can follow the remaining steps of . You can find them in chapter 3.1.5 De-Central Configuration Approach ‚Äì Create Integration Scenario Configuration, page 22.

Chapter 3.1.5 - Create Integration Scenario Configuration - Page 22

Configuration in Data Replication Framework:

Since the SAP MDG system is operated as an on-premise system in our scenario, the configuration within the Data Replication Framework (DRF) is carried out using the DRFIMG transaction. As a result, two configuration steps are required.

  • Configuration of Communication (Target) System:

Navigate to Define Custom Settings for Data Replication > Define Technical Settings > Define Technical Settings for Business Systems.

Define Technical Settings for Business System

On the first level, the Business System and Logical System must be maintained. These entries must match the corresponding settings in SOAMANAGER. Optionally, an RFC Destination can be specified (e.g., <Business System>_IDOC) if IDoc-based communication is intended.

On the second level, the relevant Business Objects are selected. For this scenario, the following objects have been configured: 147 ‚Äì Business Partner, 986 ‚Äì Business Partner including Relationships, 194 ‚Äì Product (used for product integration). The output mode has been set to D ‚Äì Direct Output. Note: Business Object 194 is not part of the Business Partner but is used exclusively for product integration.

Configuration of Communication (Target) System - 2

On the next level, the corresponding communication channels for replication via Services were assigned to Business Objects 147 and 986, as illustrated below.

Configuration of Communication (Target) System - 3

  • Configuration of Replication Model: After defining the technical settings for the target system in DRF (Business System, Logical System, and communication channels), the next step is to create and configure the replication model.

Navigate to Define Custom Settings for Data Replication > Define Replication Models.

Define Replication Models

Create a new replication Model. Therefore, select New Entries on the first level and provide a name and description for the model. This model determines which business objects will be replicated to the target system.

Define Replication Model - 1

Select the new entry and navigate to Assign Outbound Implementation on the second level. For the Business Partner replication, use Outbound Implementation 986_3 (Business Partner including Relationships), give a description and choose Communication Channel Replication via Services.

Define Replication Model - 2

After this step, select the new Outbound Implementation 986_3 and navigate to Assign Target Systems for Replication Model/Outb. Impl. on the third level. Enter the previously configured target system.

Define Replication Model - 3

At Assign Outbound Parameter we can define, how many records will be collected into a bulk message. Therefore, you can use the outbound parameter PACK_SIZE_BULK. A recommended value for this parameter is 100.

Define Replication Model - 4

After the replication model is defined, save your changes, select the replication model and choose Activate. Note that this step is required, as replication can only be executed after successful activation.

Configuration of Value Mapping

During Business Partner integration, certain code lists differ between SAP MDG and SAP S/4Public Cloud. To ensure seamless replication, these values must be mapped so that the target system correctly interprets the data sent from the source system.

Examples where value mapping is required for code lists:

  • BP groupings (DTEL MDG_FND_NR_INTERVAL_BP_GRP_COD)
  • Account groups (TABL MDG_FND_BP_MAINT_PRF_CODE)
  • Region codes (TABL MDG_FND_REGION_CODE)
  • Pricing procedure (DTEL KALKS)

Note: Although value mapping is primarily maintained in the on-premise system, certain entries may still need to be created in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using the ‚ÄúNo Mapping‚Äù indicator to avoid unnecessary mapping attempts during inbound processing.

In our scenario, we also executed the value mappings described above. The example below illustrates how Account Group value mappings are maintained in the code lists. You must decide in which system (SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud or SAP MDG) the mapping should be maintained. In our case, the mapping was performed in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Before maintaining value mappings, the relevant code lists must be assigned to the respective business systems and elements. This ensures that the replication framework knows which code list is applicable. To perform this activity, open the SAP Fiori Launchpad as Business Expert and navigate to Assign Code Lists to Elements and Systems.

Assign Code Lists to Elements & Systems

In our scenario, we assigned several code lists (such as Tax Types, Account Groups, and BP Groupings) to our MDG business system. After assignment, we defined value mappings to harmonize internal and external codes ‚Äì for example, mapping the internal tax type to external code MWST. Next, navigate to the ‚ÄúMaintain Value Mapping‚Äù app and select Position.

Select Position in Maintain Value Mapping

Enter the Object Type and Global Data Type that were assigned as code lists to the corresponding elements and system.

Enter parameter selection

 Select the relevant Value Mapping Field.

Select Value Mapping FieldAssigned Code Lists

Select the assigned code list and navigate to Define Value Mapping. Here, specify how the source system codes (SAP MDG) corresponds to the target system codes (SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud). For example, the external tax type ‚ÄúMWST‚Äù from MDG is mapped to the internal code 01 in the cloud system. This ensures consistent interpretation of data during replication.

Define Value Mapping

This example is provided for reference only to demonstrate how value mappings can be created in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Depending on your project requirements, you may need to maintain additional mappings accordingly.

3.3 Product Integration

3.3.1 Communication Arrangement for Integration Scenario SAP_COM_0009

To extend the integration beyond Business Partner data and establish the product integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the SAP MDG system, we created an additional Communication Arrangement using scenario SAP_COM_0009, which provides the required communication services for product replication.

Therefore, as before, choose ‚ÄúNew‚Äù in the ‚ÄúCommunication Arrangements‚Äù app and select the communication scenario SAP_COM_0009.

Select Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0009

As described in chapter 3.2.1, take note of the value maintained in ‚ÄúOwn SAP Cloud System‚Äù, as it is required for configuring the external MDG system. This value will be used in the target integration systems for parameters such as System Instance ID, Business System ID, and IDoc Logical System ID.

Next, select the Communication System previously created for this scenario (‚ÄúMDG‚Äù).

After selecting the Communication System, all related information, such as the Inbound Communication User, and the Service URLs of the outbound services ‚Äì will be automatically populated.

Assign Communication System & Own SAP Cloud System

For the additional properties, we selected Product Number Harmonization = 1 to ensure that product numbers from SAP MDG remain consistent in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system. By selecting setting, products are replicated with the same number as in the SAP MDG system. If the product number already exists in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the system updates the existing product rather than creating a duplicate. If the number is already used for a different product, the replication fails. In our scenario, no mapping was required because MDG was used as the leading system.

Select Value for Product Number Harmonization

In our scenario, inbound services were the most relevant because they enabled the replication of product data from SAP MDG to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Outbound services, in contrast, were not required for the main data flow.

The only outbound service we kept active was ‚ÄúProduct Master ‚Äì From S/4HANA Cloud to Client‚Äù, which is necessary to send a confirmation back to the source system (SAP MDG) after successful processing. All other outbound services can be set to ‚Äúinactive‚Äù to avoid unnecessary communication and reduce complexity.

Required Outbound Services

3.3.2 Integrate Products from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

The transfer of Product Master data from the on-premise SAP MDG system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud follows a similar process to the steps described in chapter 3.2.2, with only minor adjustments specific to the product integration.

Since the product master data replication is handled via the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0009, a different inbound service is used for this scenario.

The inbound service used for this scenario is: ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest_In

This service also includes the service group MDM_PRD_REPLICATE_REQ, which will be required later during the configuration steps in SOAMANAGER within the on-premise SAP MDG system.

Download WSDL Service Metadata for Product Integration

Configuration in Data Replication Framework:

  • Configuration of Communication (target) System:

Due to the DRF customizing in the SAP MDG transaction DRFIMG, the same target system is referenced, using Business Object 194 (Product) together with the Key Mapping as part of Key Harmonization. To configure this, navigate to: Custom Settings for Data Replication > Define Technical Settings > Define Technical Settings for Business Systems

On the first level, select the Business System and navigate to the communication channel configuration for Business Object 194 (Product). Because Key Mapping is also used for the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0009, it must additionally be configured here in the target system communication settings, as shown below.

Configuration of Communication (Target) System for Product Integration

  •  Configuration of Relocation Model:

This follows the same logic described in chapter 3.2.2. For product replication, the outbound implementation 194_3 (Product Master Data) is used.

In our scenario we used for the assigning of the outbound implementation the same replication model as for the Business Partner. Assign the same Target System as for the Business Partner. Optionally you can assign the outbound parameter PACK_SIZE_BULK which will define how many records will be collected into a bulk message.

Configuration of Replication Model for Product Integration

Value Mapping for Products:

Value mapping for product-related data follows the same principle as the Business Partner. Below is an example of value mappings already maintained in the on-premise SAP MDG system for Mechanical Engineering.

Value Mapping for Products in SAP MDG On-Premise System3.4 Configure Message Monitoring SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Accurate and timely replication of Business Partner and Product Master Data from SAP MDG on-premise to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is essential for Emission Management processes. Any replication failure can lead to incorrect assignments of emission sources, roles, or responsibilities, which may impact compliance with environmental regulations and operational safety. SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides the ‚ÄúMessage Dashboard‚Äú app to monitor replication scenarios. Before using it for the 1RO integration scenario, recipients must be assigned in the ‚ÄúAssign Recipients to Users‚Äú app.

Configuration Steps:

1. Open the ‚ÄúAssign Recipients to Users‚Äú app in the SAP Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad.

Select Assign Recipients to Users2. Verify that your user is assigned with the following details:

Namespace

Recipient Name

Message Type

Overview

Technical User

/CMDBP

CMD_BP

Application Error or Technical Error

Select the checkbox.

Select the checkbox

/CMDPR

CMD_PRODUCT

Application Error or Technical Error

Select the checkbox.

Select the checkbox.

/MDMKM

MDM_KEY_MAPP ING

Application Error or Technical Error

Select the checkbox.

Select the checkbox.

Required Recipient User Subscriptions for Monitoring - 1

If your user is not listed, add a new entry using your User ID and then assign the details of the table shown above.

Once recipients are assigned, the Message Dashboard displays all relevant replication messages ‚Äì including errors, warnings, and successfully processed records ‚Äì allowing early detection and resolution of integration issues.

Note: To reprocess messages directly from the Message Board, the user must have the SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR business role assigned. Without this role, reprocessing is not authorized.

Message Dashboard Overview:

Select Message Dashboard

The Message Dashboard provides after this setup a consolidated view of all replication messages for the 1RO scenario:

  • The calendar view indicates daily status (green = no errors, red = errors occurred).
  • Messages can be filtered by date range for detailed analysis.
  • The result list summarizes processed messages per interface (e.g. /CMDBP), including counts of warnings, technical errors, and successful replications.

This monitoring ensures transparency and operational reliability by allowing administrators to quickly identify and resolve replication issues before they impact.

Message Dashboard Overview

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing 1RO for Business Partner and Product integration ‚Äì from the SAP MDG On-Premise system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì provided several valuable insights that are highly relevant for similar integration projects.

1. Separate Replication Models Are Mandatory in DRF: Even though Business Partner and Product replication steps look similar, each requires its own replication model in DRFIMG because outbound implementations (986_3 vs 194_3) are object specific. Trying to reuse the same model can cause conflicts.

2. Service Groups Are Crucial for Dynamic Routing: The concept of service groups in SOAMANAGER is essential for Business Partner and Product replication. They enable dynamic receiver determination and simplify configuration. Ensure WSDL-based configuration is used to generate logical ports automatically.

3. Value Mapping Is Often Overlooked: Differences in code lists (e.g., BP groupings, account groups, material types) between MDG and S/4HANA Public Cloud can cause replication failures. Plan value mapping early and verify mappings in both systems.

4. Cloud Connector Setup is required for integrations from an On-Premise System into Cloud: Incorrect virtual host or missing SCC Location ID in the Communication System often leads to connectivity issues. Validate these settings before proceeding with SOAMANAGER configuration.

5. Monitoring Setup Is Critical for Operational Reliability: Assign recipients in the ‚ÄúAssign Recipients to Users‚Äù app before using the Message Dashboard. Without this, replication errors will not be visible to the right users, delaying troubleshooting.

6. Consistency in Product Number Harmonization: For Product replication, enabling ‚ÄúProduct Number Harmonization‚Äù in the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0009 prevents duplicate products and ensures updates instead of new creations. This setting is often missed.

7. Test with Small PACK_SIZE_BULK First in the DRF configuration: Start with a smaller bulk size (e.g., 10) during initial testing to simplify error analysis. Increase to the recommended 100 only after successful initial runs.

8. Documentation Alignment with 1RO: Always cross-check with SAP‚Äôs official 1RO documentation. Minor deviations (e.g., service names, WSDL variants) can lead to integration failures.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal 
  • @qkroiss 
  • @asutoshmaharana2326 
  • @kanwal_singh
  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

 Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

entry.title: üöÄ Launch Alert! Become a Data Architecture Powerhouse: Your Foundational Learning Journey
entry.content:
To equip data professionals with the skills to bridge technical expertise and strategic business impact, SAP Data Architecture experts and the SIX learning team are thrilled to announce the launch of the Data Architect Learning Journey (Foundational). This essential first stage of the Becoming a Data Architect curriculum is designed to empower aspiring architects, data professionals, and solution experts to master the core principles, modern paradigms, and critical frameworks that define successful enterprise data architecture.

 

üèóÔ∏è Structure: Building Expertise from the Ground Up

This learning journey is structured methodically, ensuring you build expertise layer by layer, from foundational theory to strategic impact.

The journey begins with Unit 1: Foundational Concepts, where you will anchor your understanding in the essential principles of modeling, metadata management, and architectural alignment. You will master basic terminologies and fundamentals, including Conceptual, Logical, and Physical data models, and understand how data architecture integrates with enterprise frameworks like Zachman and TOGAF.

Next, Unit 2: Modern Paradigms & Integration takes you into the contemporary world of data patterns. You'll explore and compare models like Data Mesh, Data Fabric, Data Lake, and Data Lakehouse, learning how to select the right approach for any scenario. This unit also delves into integration essentials, comparing and contrasting approaches such as ETL and ELT.

Unit 3 focuses on the critical need for Governance, Security & Strategic Impact. As data ecosystems expand, governance becomes the bedrock of trust. You will learn to establish comprehensive data governance frameworks (including stewardship and data lineage) and integrate crucial security and privacy controls to ensure compliance and secure modern use cases like AI/ML.

The journey culminates in Unit 4: Communicating Data Value. A great architect is also a great leader. This final unit strengthens the communication and leadership skills needed to influence change, teaching you how to articulate the limitations of the current ("as-is") data landscape and present a compelling, business-focused narrative for the future ("to-be") architecture, focusing on quality, cost, and scale.

 

üéØWho Should Enroll? Shift from Technical Expert to Strategic Leader

This curriculum is ideal for data professionals at every stage ready to evolve from technical implementers into strategic architectural leaders. This includes Data Engineers and Modelers seeking advancement, Solution and Enterprise Architects aiming to solidify their data design expertise, BI and Analytics Professionals who need architectural context, and IT and Transformation Leaders focused on aligning data systems with business outcomes.

 

‚úÖWhy Start This Journey Now?

Modern organizations demand architects who master both technology and business value. By mastering these principles, you will gain skills that directly translate into competitive advantages: you'll improve data quality and governance, learn how to connect data architecture directly to enterprise goals, and gain the credibility needed to influence strategic decisions. Crucially, this course sets the definitive foundation for the planned SAP Certified Data Architect specialization* launching in 2026!

Visit SAP Learning and enroll in the Becoming an SAP Data Architect ‚Äì Foundational Learning Journey Today! Becoming an SAP Data Architect (Foundational)

entry.title: Meet Joule: Your AI Copilot for SAP Master Data Governance
entry.content:
If there‚Äôs one thing we all want more of in our workday, it‚Äôs time. What if you could skip the clicks, stop hunting through endless menus, and just ask for the data or task you need right when you need it? That‚Äôs exactly what Joule, SAP‚Äôs powerful generative AI assistant, brings to the table. Today, we‚Äôll explore Joule‚Äôs capabilities, then zoom in on how it takes SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to a brand-new level of usability and efficiency.

What is Joule?

Joule is SAP‚Äôs generative AI assistant, designed to help you interact with your SAP systems in the simplest way: conversation. Whether you need business information, want to complete a task, or are searching for a specific insight, just ask Joule in plain language. Joule can retrieve information, complete routine tasks, guide you to the right application, or even explore your business data with you, all within the familiar SAP ecosystem.

You can work with Joule in multiple conversation threads, review or delete expired conversations, and move seamlessly between ongoing dialogues. Its capabilities are broad, spanning transactional, navigational, informational, and analytical scenarios.

 

Why Joule?

Joule is not just about simplifying tasks; it is about connecting everyone in your company, especially business users, with professional Master Data Governance (MDG) capabilities. This means that even users without extensive knowledge of MDG applications can accelerate business processes with ease. By removing the need to build custom user interfaces, Joule lowers total cost of ownership, reduces the resources needed to manage MDG, and streamlines communication by automating routine governance tasks. Here are some of the key business benefits Joule brings to your organization:

Enhanced Accessibility and Ease of Use
With Joule, access to core MDG features is democratized. Employees from any department can seamlessly engage in data governance tasks no matter where they are, eliminating the heavy reliance on specialized MDG experts. This opens up data quality and integrity efforts to a broader team and fosters a more inclusive data culture.

Efficiency in Business Processes
Joule automates routine tasks and provides intuitive conversational interfaces for complex operations. As a result, business processes move faster, and everyone spends less time managing data, leading to a significant boost in productivity.

Cost Reduction and TCO Savings
Because Joule delivers built-in, user-friendly interfaces out of the box, there is no need to invest in developing or supporting custom UIs. This helps companies save on development costs and ongoing maintenance, making the solution more cost-effective.

Improved Data Quality
By leveraging large language models to identify and correct errors, Joule helps catch anomalies and typos at the point of entry. This results in better, more consistent data from the start, supporting confident decision-making throughout the business.

Enhanced User Experience
The conversational, intuitive design of Joule makes working with complex data simpler and more enjoyable. Employees can interact with the system naturally, leading to higher satisfaction, stronger engagement, and increased productivity across the company.

Implementing Joule in your MDG landscape brings tangible business value by improving accessibility, accelerating processes, cutting costs, enhancing data quality, and ensuring scalable data management as your organization grows.

Joule for Master Data Governance: A New Era of Productivity

To  help you understand what does this base MDG Joule AI Feature in SAP Business AI Catalog offers, let‚Äôs dive into what makes Joule a game-changer for Master Data Governance.

With SAP Master Data Governance on S/4HANA 2023 FSP0 Private Cloud, customers can use following Joule capabilities to enable their business users:

Effortlessly Search and Display Business Partners

Searching for Business Partners is smarter now. You can search by almost any attribute, such as name, address, bank details, tax ID, or even birthdate:

  • ‚ÄúFind all Business Partners in Munich.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúSearch BPs with IBAN 789789.‚Äù

Joule provides results instantly and can guide you to detailed views or relevant applications for further action.

Display Business Partners

Need to look up a specific Business Partner‚Äôs information? Just type:

  • ‚ÄúShow me the bank details for BP 1234567.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúDisplay details for Business Partner 345678.‚Äù

‚ÄÉ

Joule can retrieve overviews, basic details, bank accounts, identification numbers, address usages, payment cards, roles, contact relationships, and more. You don‚Äôt need to know in advance where in the system this data resides, Joule brings it to you. Once you have the information that you need, you can open the Business Partner record from the Joule chat window or continue working on the record through Joule.

Create Business Partners  (cloud-ready mode)

Creating or updating Business Partners has never been easier. Instead of navigating multiple screens, you can tell Joule what you need in natural language:

  • ‚ÄúCreate a new organization named ABC Corp with address in Berlin.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúCreate a new person.‚Äù (and let Joule walk you through the steps)

Joule guides you through supplying only the necessary details, checks for duplicates, and creates the governance process. Of course, you can always choose to submit, retype, or decline the process‚Äîall within your conversational flow.

Edit Business Partners (cloud-ready mode) - On the Fly 

Need to update a detail? No need to open multiple transactions:

  • ‚ÄúChange the organization name for BP 1234567.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúChange the email to example@example.com for partner 4711.‚Äù

Joule manages the governance workflow for these changes, letting you save drafts, submit them for approval or even cancel as needed.

Query MDG Process (cloud-ready mode)

Joule isn‚Äôt stopping there. With S/4HANA 2025 Private Cloud, managing your governance processes just became much more intuitive:

Now, you can search not just for Business Partners, but for the governance processes themselves - across Central Governance, Consolidation, and Data Quality areas. Need to find a process by the process ID, who created it, its status, or when it was created? Just ask:

  • ‚ÄúShow my last process.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúFind high priority processes from last week.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúDisplay all processes created by John.‚Äù

Once you find a process, Joule brings you the essential details: process ID, status, priority, and more. Need to understand what‚Äôs going on with a particular record? Request:

  • ‚ÄúShow me the details of process 1234.‚Äù

And from there, you can jump straight to related Business Partner data or the relevant management app.

Bringing It Together

Joule is redefining how we interact with Master Data Governance in SAP. With intuitive conversational access, you can create, search, display, and edit Business Partners or even manage governance processes - without losing your flow or context. No more clicking through menus or remembering transaction codes. You get instant, accurate responses, all backed by the power and security of SAP.

Ready to work smarter? Meet Joule, and experience next-level productivity in Master Data Governance. Take a moment to also check our video on the newest Joule capabilities in MDG with demos and examples.

Interested in learning more about Joule‚Äôs capabilities or how to enable it for your team? Reach out to your SAP contact or check out the SAP Help Portal for the latest documentation and setup guides.

entry.title: Hidden Crisis: Ageing Infrastructure, Reactive O&M, and the Data Problem No One Is Solving
entry.content:
Why ageing infrastructure and reactive maintenance are accelerating into a classic hockey-stick cost curve for oil and gas industry, and how trusted master data is the only realistic path to predictive excellence.

Dr. Imad Syed, CEO, PiLog Group 

The oil and gas (O&G) industry remains one of the world‚Äôs most critical sources of primary energy, shaping global economic stability and long-term development. Yet behind this strategic importance lies an accelerating challenge: an ageing infrastructure that is pushing operations and maintenance (O&M) into a reactive, high-cost spiral.

Many upstream and midstream assets ‚Äì platforms, pipelines, processing units and refineries ‚Äì are now 20-30 years old. Science journal, Nature, found that many of the world‚Äôs 12,000 offshore platforms are nearing their end-of-life. More than 3,000 installations in the North Sea and Gulf of Mexico have already exceeded 25-30 years of operation.

Ageing assets drive a predictable but costly pattern: the ‚Äúhockey-stick‚Äù curve of O&M costs. As corrosion, fouling, fatigue, and obsolete parts accumulate, operators are forced into more inspections, more emergency work, more reverse-engineering, and ultimately more unplanned shutdowns. Downtime alone can exceed $1 million per day per asset. Global outages contribute to more than 10 million barrels per day of lost production ‚Äì representing nearly $200 billion in annual revenue foregone.

Our analysis of 18 global publicly listed O&G companies reveals that O&M already represents 18% of their total operating costs, rising to as high as 35% for some players. This cost pressure is magnified whenever price cycles trigger deferred maintenance, compounding future reliability risk.

 Why Digital Investments Alone Don‚Äôt Solve the Problem

The industry has responded with aggressive investments in digital technologies. Global O&G digital transformation spend reached an estimated $77-90 billion in 2024 and is projected to rise to $90-124 billion in 2025: approximately 10-15% of upstream/downstream CAPEX.

Some leaders, including ExxonMobil, Chevron, and Saudi Aramco report strong returns through reduced downtime and optimized assets. However, scaling remains the industry‚Äôs biggest weakness: only 13-36% of firms have taken successful pilots into full-scale operations. Nearly 60-70% remain stuck in pilot mode.

The root cause is clear:

Digital tools generate data, but most O&G operators lack the foundational master data integrity required to turn that data into reliable decisions.

Sensors proliferate, but only 13% of companies use this data strategically. Legacy systems Maximo, ERP, SCADA, CMMS, engineering repositories, procurement databases hold conflicting records of the same assets, parts, BOMs, locations, and vendors. Without a ‚Äòsingle version of the truth‚Äô, predictive models cannot be trusted, digital twins cannot remain accurate, and planners spend more time reconciling than optimizing.

The result: fragmented data, stalled initiatives, and a widening gap between digital ambition and operational reality.

Master Data Management (MDM): The Missing Foundation for O&M Transformation

Master Data Management is not a ‚Äúdata-cleaning exercise‚Äù,  it is a structural capability that enables oil & gas operators to control the lifecycle, quality, and reliability of asset, equipment, material, and vendor data across all systems. When done properly, it directly addresses both the ageing infrastructure challenge and the industry‚Äôs deeply reactive maintenance culture.

MDM gives operators:

  • A single asset golden record (industry-specific) that integrates engineering, EAM, CMMS, inspection, procurement, and sensor data
  • Clean, enriched, audit-ready records of equipment, parts, hierarchies, and BOMs
  • Governance workflows that ensure every change is approved, traceable, and compliant
  • The ability to feed digital twins and AI engines with trusted, high-quality data
  • The foundation required to shift from reactive to predictive maintenance                                                                            

Strengthening Asset Integrity for Ageing Infrastructure

Integrity management depends on reliable equipment history, correct system hierarchies, validated inspection data, and traceable change records. Ageing assets amplify the consequences of poor data ‚Äì small inaccuracies can lead to missed integrity threats and unplanned shutdowns.

MDM provides:

  • A unified asset master data record (tag, serial, function, location, BOM, history, specs, certificates, maint. plan, etc)
  • Cleansing and enrichment with OEM data, calibration records, and criticality ratings
  • Governance that ensures every change, a modification, retrofit, or decommissioning is documented and approved

The result is an asset register that becomes the single, authoritative source for risk-based integrity planning and regulatory compliance.

 Moving Beyond Reactive Maintenance to Predictive Excellence

Predictive maintenance cannot succeed without clean, consistent, and connected master data. AI/ML models rely on correct sensor-to-asset mapping, harmonized failure codes, and trustworthy historical labels.

MDM enables:

  • Accurate ‚Äúsensor ‚Üí asset ‚Üí system‚Äù mapping
  • High-quality historical maintenance data aligned to standard failure modes
  • Enriched material masters with lead times, alternate parts, and criticality
  • Validated data flows into PdM engines, digital twins, and planning systems

Industry estimates indicate that predictive-maintenance excellence made possible by reliable master data can reduce unplanned downtime by 20-30% and cut maintenance costs by 5-15%, rising to 20-30% with advanced AI-based scheduling and spares optimization.

 Reducing Costs Through Better Materials, Spares, and Inventory Data

Good master data creates quantifiable value:

  • Lower inventory and working-capital costs
  • Fewer emergency purchases
  • Higher first-time fix rates
  • Better compliance and reporting
  • Faster work-order planning and execution

O&G companies frequently carry 10-25% duplicate materials, which directly inflate procurement and storage costs. Clean, standardized material masters eliminate duplication, enforce catalogue discipline, and drive more strategic sourcing.

Case 1: The Real Cost of Bad Master Data in Oil & Gas / Petrochemicals

Symptom

Typical Annual Cost (per site)

Source

Duplicate / obsolete spares

$5‚Äì25 M

Solomon, Accenture, McKinsey

Excess inventory carrying cost (25‚Äì35 %)

$3‚Äì12 M

Deloitte 2024

Emergency purchases & expediting fees

$2‚Äì8 M

ARC Advisory

Unplanned downtime from ‚Äúwrong part‚Äù

0.5‚Äì3 % of revenue (~$10‚Äì60 M for large refinery/upstream asset)

Solomon RAM Studies

Contractor inefficiency (re-work, waiting, repeated mobilizations)

15‚Äì40 % premium

EY, Bain

Total hidden cost: easily $20‚Äì80 M per year for a large refinery or offshore platform.

Case 2: Three Areas Where Clean Master Data Delivers Immediate ROI

  1. Increasing Maintenance Budget (without asking for more money)
    • Clean equipment hierarchies + accurate BOMs ‚Üí 20‚Äì40 % reduction in emergency work orders
    • Accurate failure codes and catalog profiles ‚Üí better MTBF data ‚Üí defensible reliability projects
    • Result: You re-allocate 10‚Äì25 % of existing maintenance spend from reactive to preventive/predictive ‚Üí effectively ‚Äúcreates‚Äù new budget
  2. Optimizing Spares Inventory (freeing up cash or hording cost)
    • De-duplication projects typically remove 12‚Äì15 % of Spares
    • Accurate min-max driven by real consumption (not guesswork) ‚Üí 20‚Äì30 % inventory reduction in 12‚Äì18 months
    • Standardized material descriptions ‚Üí vendor consolidation ‚Üí source of supply mapping ‚Üí 8‚Äì15 % purchase price reduction
    • Real case: Middle East refinery freed $38 M working capital in 14 months after master data cleanse
  3. Optimizing Inbound Services & Contractor Spend
    • Clean functional locations + Clean equipment classification + standardized task lists ‚Üí standardized BOMs ‚Üí work packs issued with 95 %+ material availability
    • Accurate service master and vendor master (service provider) ‚Üí automated 3-way match ‚Üí 98 % touchless invoicing
    • Result: 25‚Äì40 % reduction in contractor waiting time and repeated mobilizations
    • Example: North Sea operator cut turnaround contractor cost by 18 % in 2024 just by fixing material master and BOMs

How PiLog‚Äôs DQG Suite Delivers These Outcomes

Together with SAP, PiLog has embarked on a partnership journey to address these industry challenges.  Complementing and enriching SAP Intelligent Asset Management, PiLog‚Äôs Data Quality and Governance (DQG) Suite is built to deliver the exact MDM capabilities required for aging infrastructures, predictive maintenance, and integrated O&M operations. The solution is Endorsed and Premium Certified with over 200+ real-time integrations ready to deploy on-premise, private cloud & SaaS public cloud for SAP Cloud ERP Private & Public editions.

The suite provides:

  • End-to-end data migration, standardization, cleansing, enrichment, and governance
  • AI-enabled classification based on ISO 81346 and ISO 14224
  • Harmonized assets, equipment, and material records for SAP EAM, APM, and S/4HANA
  • Seamless integration with SAP APM, FSM, IBP (MRO), BNAC & Ariba
  • A foundation for digital twins, predictive maintenance, and data-driven operational excellence

Common Pain Points Identified Across PiLog‚Äôs O&G Customers

  • Duplicate or inconsistent material masters
  • Unstructured PR/PO creation and poor service masters
  • Missing or incomplete asset and equipment masters
  • Multi-entity inconsistencies across business groups

Quantifiable Improvements Delivered

  • Up to 25% duplicate detection and elimination
  • Up to 15% reduction in inventory hoarding
  • 12% YoY reduction in O&M costs
  • 22%+ reduction in sourcing and procurement cost

These results demonstrate that master data is not an IT function, it is an operational performance driver.

 Aging Assets Are Inevitable ‚Äì Reactive O&M Is Not

The industry cannot stop infrastructure from ageing. But it can change how it responds.

Digital investments alone will not close the reliability gap. A foundational shift to high-quality master data, governed, enriched, standardized, and connected across all systems ‚Äì is what allows O&G companies to control the cost curve, extend asset life, and move decisively toward predictive maintenance excellence.

With the right master data foundations, operators can break the cycle of reactive firefighting and build a more reliable, safer, and economically resilient O&M model.

* References can be provided upon request

entry.title: üöÄ Ignite Your Data Architecture Journey: Empower Enterprise and Data Architects Today!
entry.content:
In the era of digital transformation, data is the heartbeat of innovation, strategy, and impactful decision-making. Strong Data Architecture is the foundation that powers every thriving enterprise. To bridge technical expertise with strategic business outcomes, the SAP Data Architecture experts alongside the SIX learning team proudly unveil the Data Architect Learning Journey (Foundational).

This inaugural phase of the Becoming a Data Architect program is crafted to equip aspiring architects, data professionals, and solution experts with essential frameworks, modern methodologies, and core principles that shape successful enterprise data architectures.

 

üèóÔ∏è Layered Learning: From Fundamentals to Enterprise Impact

This journey guides you through a carefully designed progression to build your expertise methodically:

  • Unit 1: Foundational Concepts anchors you in the fundamentals‚Äîmastering modeling techniques, metadata management, and the integration of data architectures with enterprise frameworks such as Zachman and TOGAF. Grasp the essentials of Conceptual, Logical, and Physical models that form the backbone of data design.

  • Unit 2: Modern Paradigms & Integration immerses you in today‚Äôs evolving landscape, exploring advanced patterns like Data Mesh, Data Fabric, Data Lake, and Data Lakehouse. Understand when and how to apply each, plus gain insights into key integration frameworks, including the nuances between ETL and ELT strategies.

  • Unit 3: Governance, Security & Strategic Value addresses the growing need to establish trust and compliance within expansive data ecosystems. Delve into comprehensive data governance frameworks‚Äîdata stewardship, lineage, and privacy safeguards that secure modern architectures and enable AI/ML innovations.

  • Unit 4: Communicating Data Value sharpens your leadership voice, guiding you to communicate complex architectural changes clearly and compellingly. Learn to narrate the journey from the current state to future architecture, emphasizing quality, cost-efficiency, and scalability to align with business priorities.

 

üéØWho Should Embark?

Designed for data professionals ready to evolve beyond technical roles into influential architectural strategists, this foundation suits:

  • Data Engineers and Modelers aspiring to architect-level roles

  • Solution and Enterprise Architects deepening their data design acumen

  • BI and Analytics experts seeking architectural context

  • IT and Transformation leaders aligning data strategies with business goals

 

‚úÖWhy Now? Gain a Strategic Edge

Today‚Äôs enterprises demand architects who not only understand technology but who can also drive meaningful business outcomes. This journey empowers you to enhance data quality, governance, and alignment with enterprise strategies‚Äîskills that translate directly into leadership credibility and competitive advantage. Plus, it sets the stage for the upcoming SAP Certified Data Architect specialization, launching in 2026.

 

üõ£Ô∏è Begin Your Path to Architecting Tomorrow

Ready to elevate your data architectural mindset and lead transformative initiatives? No prerequisites required‚Äîstart your journey today!

Enroll now at SAP Learning: Becoming an SAP Data Architect ‚Äì Foundational Learning Journey!

entry.title: Recommendation/Best Practice for SAP Master Data Governance Extensibility in Classic Mode
entry.content:
Introduction to Clean Core in S/4HANA

With the introduction of MDG Cloud Ready Mode in SAP S/4HANA 2023, SAP has significantly intensified its emphasis on maintaining a clean core. SAP‚Äôs objective is clear: Organizations must transition toward a clean core, a system landscape where customizations are isolated from the core application, ensuring long-term stability, predictable upgrades, and seamless adoption of innovations delivered by SAP.

Customers opting for Cloud Ready Mode encounter stricter guardrails around extensibility. Traditional enhancement patterns‚Äîsuch as modifications, implicit enhancements, or pervasive use of custom code within standard classes‚Äîare heavily restricted. Only those extension approaches that guarantee lifecycle stability and upgrade resilience are supported.

Implications for MDG Customers in Classic Mode

For organizations currently using MDG in Classic Mode, but intending to maintain system stability and ensure smooth, low-effort upgrades, it becomes essential to adopt an extension strategy that aligns closely with clean-core guidelines. The extension approach must strike a balance between functional requirements and long-term maintainability, particularly in upgrade-intensive environments.

Organizations in Classic Mode face pressing questions:

  • How do we continue enhancing MDG without jeopardizing upgrade stability?
  • Which extensibility options remain viable, and which should be avoided?
  • How can we design custom logic that aligns with SAP‚Äôs forward-looking roadmap?
  • What development patterns minimize rework in future upgrades?

Recommended Extensibility Approach

Following SAP‚Äôs clean-core philosophy, the recommended extensibility hierarchy is as follows:

1. Key User In-App Extensibility

Preferred for UI and lightweight business logic enhancements, designed to be upgrade-safe and lifecycle-stable

2. Side-by-Side Extensibility

Ideal for more complex or custom business processes using SAP BTP, providing isolation from the S/4HANA digital core while ensuring deep integration through released APIs and events

3. Classic Extensibility

Classic extensions remain available in MDG Classic Mode, but they should be used sparingly and only when clean-core options cannot fulfil the requirement.

Classic extensibility includes:

  • BADIs specific to MDG
  • Enhancement points
  • Derivation and validation exits
  • Custom code within allowed enhancement frameworks

Considerations for MDG Extension Design

There have been attempts in Classic Mode to build wrapper classes around SAP standard MDG classes with the intention of stabilizing custom logic across upgrades. However, given the expanding set of released APIs and whitelisted objects, attempting to wrap all MDG-specific classes is time-consuming.

A more sustainable approach is to rely on:

  • Released MDG APIs, frameworks, and BAdIs
  • Workflow and rule-based configurability
  • Event-driven extension patterns via SAP BTP
  • Governance processes aligned with clean-core principles

 

Below table will outline the recommended and prioritized extension options for MDG in Classic Mode, offering guidance for customers seeking to preserve upgrade stability while aligning with SAP‚Äôs recommended enhancement strategy.

We will continue to revise and update the above list, as and when new scenarios and capabilities are identified.
